definition: big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother

sentences.english: a. The economy of China will merge into the tide of the world economy. b. The economy of China will converge with that of the world economy.
sentences.chinese: 中国的经济将融入世界经济的大潮。

sentences.english: In reformatory tide they should become the overmatch in competition to enhance their position.
sentences.chinese: 在改革的大潮中做竞争的强者，提高自己的地位。

sentences.english: Chian 's WTO entry markes that Chinese economy starts to blend in the spring tide of the world economy.
sentences.chinese: 加入WTO，标志着中国经济开始融入世界经济大潮。

sentences.english: A saltwater wedge may be found when the sea water encroaches on the estuary during the plentiful runoff and spring tide.
sentences.chinese: 闽江河口丰水大潮期盐水入侵过程中可见到盐水楔。

sentences.english: However, today the economy of billowy reforms spring tide in.
sentences.chinese: 然而，在今天汹涌澎湃的经济改革大潮中。

sentences.english: Since ancient times, qiantang river tide, called world wonders.
sentences.chinese: 钱塘江大潮，自古以来被称为天下奇观。

sentences.english: She wasn't sheded in the bout of downsizing.
sentences.chinese: 在那次精简人员的大潮中，她幸运地保住了她的工作。

sentences.english: The great Asian investment - banking recruitment rush has slowed, but it hasn't ended.
sentences.chinese: 洲投资银行业招新大潮已放缓，但并未结束。

sentences.english: Originally true appearance is descended all by the sediment of the ages big tide bind to ride on to drift everywhere.
sentences.chinese: 本真状态，被泥沙俱下的时代大潮裹挟着四处漂流。

sentences.english: Tang dynasty witnessed a sub-clan of Gao migrating south to Fujian.
sentences.chinese: 唐代，高姓中的一支随中原南移大潮进入福建。

definition: a powerful current/a flood (often fig., e.g. a flood of ideas)
tempest/wave (of popular sentiment etc)/craze or fad
to surge like a gathering storm (idiom)/to grow by leaps and bounds
flourishing and still in the ascendant (idiom); rapidly expanding/still growing strong/on the up
to rise/to spring up/to burgeon/to be aroused/to come into vogue
to lift/to raise in height/to begin/upsurge/to set off (a campaign)
storm/violent commotion/fig. crisis (e.g. revolution, uprising, financial crisis etc)
to surge up violently (of ocean, river, lake etc)/turbulent
to reform and open to the outside world/refers to Deng Xiaoping's policies from around 1980
